paragraph: “What was hidden in the shell,     Was born through the power of fiery torments.     From this first arose love,     As the germ of knowledge,     The wise found the roots of existence in non-existence,     By investigating the hearts impulses.”[768]This philosophical view interprets the world as an emanation of the libido, and this must be widely accepted from the theoretic as well as the psychologic standpoint, for the function of reality is an instinctive function, having the character of biological adaptation. When the insane Schreber brought about the end of the world through his libido-introversion, he expressed an entirely rational psychologic view, just as Schopenhauer wished to abolish through negation (holiness, asceticism) the error of the primal will, through which the world was created. Does not Goethe say:“You follow a false trail;         Do not think that we are not serious;         Is not the kernel of nature         In the hearts of men?”The hero, who is to accomplish the rejuvenation of the world and the conquest of death, is the libido, which, brooding upon itself in introversion, coiling as a snake around its own egg, apparently threatens life with a poisonous bite, in order to lead it to death, and from that darkness, conquering itself, gives birth to itself again. Nietzsche knows this conception:[769]“How long have you sat already upon your misfortune.      Give heed! lest you hatch an egg,      A basilisk egg      Of your long travail.”
question: What philosophical view is described in the text, and how is it related to the concept of libido?
answer: The philosophical view described in the text interprets the world as an emanation of the libido. This view is rooted in both theoretical and psychological perspectives, suggesting that the function of reality is an instinctive function with the character of biological adaptation. The text emphasizes that the libido, when introspected, can lead to a transformation that both threatens and rejuvenates life.
